text: Gunfire lights up the room. Two guns fire back. A silhoue collapses. Silence and darkness. Eli scratches a match and lights tw lamps. He hands one to Charlie. They walk around the room stepping over corpses. Four of them.  2. Lamp light on the corpses’ faces. One man is still breath Charlie sits him up.
Where’s Blount? Blood froths on the man’s lips. Charlie shakes him.
Blount? The man coughs. Charlie finishes him off. Something on the ceiling catches Eli’s attention: dust trickling from between the planks.

Up in the attic, dry and dark. A scared man cowers behind bales of hay. Blount. His hands scratch at the wooden slats of the roof, rippin away straw and adobe. He hears footsteps on the steps of the ladder. He groans. In the hole of the roof, a chunk of sky appear the moon... Footsteps on the attic floor. Blount slips through the opening...
--- rolls, falls from the roof... ... lies on the ground, the wind knocked out of him... He sits up...
Blount? Blount turns around. Charlie barely aims. Shoots. Blount collapses. Charlie shoots twice to finish him off, then turns to the ranch and reloads.
Charlie! Charlie!  Suddenly: Eli’s voice is heard from above. Charlie steps away. He looks up and sees his brother in the hole in the roof, pointing to something.

The barn! He hears something galloping behind him. He turns around, clutching his gun. A horse on fire gallops through the landscape. 5A EXT BARN BLOUNT’S RANCH-NIGHT: The barn is on fire. Through the flames, we see the silhouettes of horses panicking. Shielding their faces, the two brothers try to penetrate inferno.
What are you doing?
I’m not walking home !

Eli ! Don’t be fucking stupid, let's go ! They’re just fucking horses ! On his last try, Eli comes running back out with his coat fire. He rolls around on the ground to put out the flames Charlie helps him. Helpless, they hear their horses neigh in terror. 5B EXT BARN. BLOUNT FARM-NIGHT. In the background, the barn is still burning.
How many you think we've killed?
I don’t know, six, seven?

Well, we fucked that up real good. They disappear into the night.  6A EXT COMMODORE’S MANSION-DAY: It is gray and cold. Hard to tell if it is dawn or dusk. The dark silhouette of a huge Neo-Gothic building. On the gate, a sign with the owner’s coat of arms: a sun shining a globe, stamped with an anchor. It is the Commodore’s mansion. On the other side of the white fence, Eli Sisters is wait on a low-backed horse, slumped like a sagging sofa - “Tub Eli is dressed sloppily, his stomach protrudes over his b He looks at the horse attached beside him: a superb Spani Barb horse, large and muscled - “Nimble”. He shakes his h in disbelief. He looks back at the manor house. A silhouette appears at first floor window. It is his brother Charlie, in the glo oil-burning lamps. Then another silhouette appears beside him, a smaller, wh haired man, dressed in black: the Commodore. 6B EXT. COMMODORE’S MANSION-DAY : Charlie is coming back. He looks dirty and sloppy too, bu thin and naturally elegant.
What did the Commodore say? Did you mention the horses?
Let's go get a drink. Eli tries to catch up with his brother.
The brothers are sitting in the back of a saloon. Not man customers at the bar. Charlie is drinking brandy. Eli is drinking less. Charlie speaks softly.
He said if there’d been a lead man, we wouldn’t have had problems at the Blount ranch. He says for the next job, we need to have a lead man.
What’s it mean about money?
More for me.
No. My money, I mean. Same as before?
Well, no. Less, obviously. Eli makes a face. Charlie pours him a glass to keep him c
The Commodore wants to pay for a lead man, that’s fine. But it’s bad business to short the man underneath.
You're not asking what the job is?
No.
I’1l tell you anyways. We have to go South and find Morris.
The Commodore’s John Morris? ..-And why do we have to find this Morris? Charlie downs his glass, he leans over to Eli.
He’s after a prospector named Hermann Kermit Warm.
Great. He can find him and kill him. End of story.
Morris is a scout, not a killer. The mission is: Morris finds Warm, he holds him, we come in and finish the job. That’s the mission. Eli thinks it over.
What about the horses?
What’s your goddamn problem with the horses?
The Commodore told us he would get us new horses!
Isn’t that what he did?
No. For you he got a new horse. For me, he made room in his stable and got rid of some horse meat.
Don’t you think we can talk about this later?
No, I don’t need the horse later, I need it now, for the job! The bartender comes to take the bottle and get paid.
The horse is fine, stop being a baby.
Is it the words “go halves” that you don’t like? To the bartender, seeing that Charlie isn’t budging.
The lead’s man paying

head_text.subj: EXT. OREGON CITY SALOON STREET DAY

text: They cross the street to their horses. We discover the town: a prosperous, thriving western city
In a prairie, a small log cabin. Their horses are tied in front

The inside is rudimentary. Each brother is in what serves his room, packing for the trip. Charlie’s room looks like sty, Eli’s is clean and tidy. On one of the “living room” walls is a framed landscape c out of a newspaper. Charlie shifts the frame to uncover a hiding place. He gropes inside and pulls out a few bills, then a few gold pieces. He counts them and places them in large wallet. ool se Eli cuts his hair in front of a dusty mirror. His long ha falls on the ground strand by strand. He calls for Charli help.
Hey, come cut the back of this for me. Just cut it off. Charlie smiles at Eli’s face in the mirror.
You look funny like that. woe] oe Eli takes a red woolen shawl from the dresser drawer and folds it with particular care.
Eli mounts Tub, who seems to buck under his weight. He digs his spurs in the horse’s flank, the horse balks.. joins Charlie. The two men leave the log cabin and prairie behind.

A relay station, further south.  8. Sitting at a small table in the shade of the verandah, a is writing a letter. His clothes are elegant and understa He is well groomed, fine-featured and strong. A handsome John Morris, 35.

Dear solicitor, my friend, My father had vowed to do two things. First, to do whatever it takes to ruin my life. And second, to disinherit me. He kept his word for the first. Not for the second. It surprises me, and I attribute it to his declining health. In any case, I want nothing of this inheritance: not the titles, the factory, the buildings or the Westwood property... I want nothing. I’l1l be back in Washington before winter. We will deal with all these details then. I shake your hand. Your friend, John Morris. Across from him, the landscape pulses under the sun. John folds his letter.
The letter disappears into a big leather sack marked “Mai
When did the last wagon train pass through?
Yesterday.
I'm looking for a guy named Warm. Hermann Kermit Warm, 5 foot 6, lean, dark skin, no bags or gear. He’s traveling in a wagon train. The owner did not see Warm.

John Morris heads back to his curly horse, built to ride and hard. They head down the trail. The mare immediately launches into a perfect half-gallop.  9. Torso straight, feet in the stirrups, John Morris rides o like a Mongol horseman.
Tall grass blowing in the wind. On their horses, side by side, the brothers slowly cross large, sloping landscape.
Gorgeous country, isn’t it? Odd we haven’t seen anyone since this morning.
If we’d stayed on the trail, we'd have come across more people.
Yeah, but it’s nothing like what they say. Supposedly the whole world is searching for gold! Honestly...
They set up camp and finish eating by the fire.
What did this Hermann Warm do?
He stole something from the Commodore. Eli thinks it over.
Don’t you find it strange, all these men foolish enough to steal from such a dangerous man? Charlie has no opinion.
How do they even steal anything at all? We know how cautious the Commodore is.  10.
Caution has nothing to do with it. He does business in every corner of the country, and even overseas. A man can’t be everywhere at once. It stands to reason he’d be victimized.
Victimized?!?
Yes, victimized.
The Commodore is «victimized»?
What would you call it? If a man is forced to protect his fortune with the likes of us?
Not “victimized”...
You're not going to start nitpicking over every word. What’s your problem? Are you upset?
You’re upset that I’m the lead man? Is that it? If that’s it,just say so. But stop splitting hairs...

I’m not splitting hairs! You’re using a strange word and I’m making you take notice... Charlie drops his tin pan and goes to his corner to sprea open his blanket. According to a well-established routine, Eli collects the pans and silverware, and then stokes the fire.

Eli spreads out a first blanket, then lays a patchwork qu on top. He winds his pocket watch, puts it next to his “pillow” and lies down.  11. Nearby, Charlie lets out a loud fart. Eli checks his watch and moves the big hand up to the 9.
They climb up a steep path, spurring the horses on. They at the top and let the horses catch their breath.
Ccould it be Miss Emilia Patridge?
What are you talking about?
It’s the schoolteacher who gave you that silly red scarf... (imitating him) The one you keep folding and unfolding in secret?
It’s called a shawl. Am I not entitled to any privacy?
Have you made plans with this Miss Emilia?
Plans?
To marry her, start a family, have children... something like that.
I don’t know. Why are you so interested all of a sudden?
I was wondering about family. You remember how Pa was with Ma?
Yes, Charlie, I remember.
Makes you think... You’re not scared to reproduce yourself?  12.
You do realize that our father was stark-raving mad and that we got his foul blood in our veins?
Our father drank, Charlie. Charlie looks at him seriously, then smiles.
That was his gift to us. That blood. That’s why we’re good at what we do. 16 EXT HILL WARM’S CARAVAN POV DAY:

POV from a pair of binoculars: a caravan of three covered wagons struggles up a hill. We see the drivers whip their horses. The passengers get and push. The binoculars remain on the wagons and men. When they have reached the top of the hill, the passenger climb back into the wagons. The binoculars stop on the wagon bringing up the rear, an the man who just sat against the rear slat: Hermann Kermit Warm. 16B EXT HILL WARM’S CARAVAN DAY: John Morris puts away his binoculars. He starts off, at a distance from the caravan.
From the saloon door, Morris watches a house being built. Warm is one of the workmen. He watches him saw planks, assemble beams and direct the maneuver to hoist the facad  13.
At the end of the day, Morris sees the owner of the house hand Warm some coins for his labor.

May 15th. Myrtle Creek, Oregon. The gold rush has made the detective’s job much easier. When you look for a woman, a man, a horse or a dog, just follow the gold. And soon enough you'll find whom or what you’re after. Hermann Kermit Warm, eats messily, 5 foot 6, lean, dark skin, no friends, no baggage, no money.

head_text.subj: EXT/INT. PIONEER TOWN 01/ TENT CAMP DAY

text: Morris sees Warm back in the encampment, where he pays a of soup, and lies for down on a cot. He pulls up the cover over his head and lies still.
A wagon train is about to depart. Hermann Kermit Warm cli aboard the last wagon. At the village outskirts, Morris waits for the caravan to disappear before setting off on his own.

head_text.subj: 21A INT PIONEER TOWN 02 TRADING POST DAY

text: Charlie and Eli are covered in sweat and dust.
Sisters. S-I-S-T-E-R-S, like sisters. Behind the counter, a storekeeper in an undershirt and an apron tenses up when he hears their name. He stops looking through the mail left there to be picked
No, nothing. I’d have remembered.  14.
No news is good news. What’s the next town on the trail?
Myrtle Creek.
How far?
Two days.

head_text.subj: 21B INT PIONEER TOWN 02 TRADING POST DAY

text: Eli walks around the store. Every possible accoutrement f prospecting: pans, cradles, buckets, pickaxes, a dismantl model of Long Tom, oil lamps, clothing made of fabric, of leather... The store is dark and luminous at the same tim is enthralled, curious... He stops in front of a small metal box. Inside, a small b with a wooden handle. He picks it up and studies it. The storekeeper comes by.
Interested?
What is it?
A toothbrush, sir. To keep your teeth longer and your breath fresher. Look. He opens a box of tooth powder and shoves it under his no He sniffs. Smells good.
What kind of boots do you have?
I'll be with you right away, sir!

head_text.subj: EXT PIONEER TOWN 02 SALOON STREET EVENING

text: A small town, but lively. The brothers walk down Main Str Eli is carrying his small package from the store.  15. Charlie is freshly outfitted from head to toe. You can al hear his clothes crinkling.
You know, when we stop, that’s the kind of store I’d like to have.
When we stop what?
Killing people! I believe I could settle into a life like that. Didn't it seem pleasant in there?
I'd die of boredom.
It seemed peaceful enough to me. I bet that man sleeps very well at night.
Because that’s the point? To sleep well at night? You don’t sleep well at night?
No, and neither do you.
Me? You must be kidding. I sleep like a baby.
Says you! You grit your teeth, and sometimes you cry.
I cry?!?
Yes, you cry. Charlie stares at him, smirks.
What are you talking about? Are you trying to tell me something?  16.
We're talking... I’m just telling you the truth.
Yeah, right. (he hands his saddlebags to his brother) Put this in the room. We’1ll meet up later. Eli crosses the street loaded down and heads for the salo

head_text.subj: INT PIONEER TOWN 02 HOTEL ROOM EVENING

text: Naive black and white drawings illustrating how to use th toothbrush. A small hotel room. Eli brushes his teeth according to the instructions. He i diligent and excessive, as if inventing a style. He sits in front of the window overlooking the street and entrance to the saloon. Eli blows into his cupped hands to smell his new breath.

head_text.subj: EXT PIONEER TOWN 02 SALOON STREET NIGHT

text: Night has fallen. Eli is in the street. He finishes eating something, all the while looking out t corner of his eye at the saloon. Inside, Charlie is in the middle of a conversation with a in a suit and hat. They have both been drinking. Charlie admires the revolver hanging from his belt. The man hands to him. Charlie weighs it in his hand. He likes its proportions. When he hands it back, his mouth is smiling, not his eyes.

head_text.subj: EXT PIONEER TOWN 02 / TENT ENCAMPMENT NIGHT

text: Eli wanders through the tents at the town limits. There a people in all kinds of attire, speaking all kinds of languages, guttural and crystalline.  17. He notices Russian astrakhan hats and the strange pointy of Shtetl Jews. Leaning over a cauldron, a woman sells soup for a few cen She serves him a bowl. He eats.
It’s good. Is it vegetables?
Bortsch.
I taste dill.
Bortsch ! The woman does not understand. He gives up. He hears chanting from behind. He approaches. Finishing h soup, he watches a family observe the Sabbath ritual.

Eli is asleep. Shouts, gunshots coming from the street wa him up. He grabs his gun and runs to the window. Down below, in the middle of the street, Charlie is teete with a gun in each hand. He shoots into the air.
Five... Six... are you counting? Seven, eight... Nine! Oh where did you go? Where did you go ? The saloon and the street empty. Silhouettes cautiously h the facades. The street is now deserted.
You fucking cowards... No one wants to measure themselves up against Charlie Sisters?! No one really? Eli goes back to bed.
Go home you fools...  18.
The noise is coming closer. When the door opens, Eli turn the wall and shuts his eyes. The room now echoes with Charlie’s heavy breathing and groans.

+. And that idiot, fast asleep... What good are you?... Damn, if you weren’t my brother, I'd have ditched you ages ago... Even the Commodore wanted to ... “Why do you carry around that dead weight?”... “Because he’s my brother, I answered. We all have our fucking crosses to bear!"”... He appreciated how loyal I am. “Faith will be repaid with faith,” he said. A beat. Then suddenly, right next to Eli’s ear, the click a revolver being cocked. Eli opens his eyes and looks at brother. Above him, Charlie’s revolver is aimed at him.
-.. Tst-tst... It’s not nice to fake it.
Go to sleep.
Can I ask you a question, brother? Who can have faith in you? Real faith? Huh? He lifts his hand sententiously and stumbles off to bed.

They are riding their horses across the Willamette Valley Eli is sullen. Charlie is riding behind, slumped over Nimble’s neck. All of a sudden, Eli hears a big thump. Ja he stops Tub... He dismounts and steps toward Charlie, lying on the groun He lifts him up, not gently. His new outfit is now dirty. Charlie feels nauseous.Eli turns around. He hears Charlie vomit. Eli grabs him roughly and helps him back into the saddle.  19.
Don’t judge me, please. Some days we're stronger than others.
They are riding one behind the other. Eli remains silent. Charlie is feeling a bit better.
You okay? Charlie catches up to ELi.
Are you pouting? No answer.
Is it because I drank? Eli feels Charlie staring at him. He stops Tub.
Listen, either ride in front or ride in back, but I don’t feel like talking.

It’s just like I said: you’re pouting. You’re ruining the atmosphere on purpose. We could have had a delightful day and you took it on yourself to ruin it... Oh, fuck it. Pout if you want to. He spurs Nimble and takes the lead.

Well, if you insist on pouting, you should give it your all. Give us a full pout, Eli. You must stew and hate and revisit all the slights I offered you in childhood. Don’t you forget a single one! Eli smiles slightly.  20.
No, you mustn’t smile when pouting! It’s wrong and you know it’s wrong!
Heavy fog. Another pioneer town on the trail. As usual, t is one main street, wood houses and store signs. John Morris shakily crosses the muddy street on wooden pl that have been laid down.
Morris is having dinner at a table in the back. Without having to look up from his notebook, he feels Warm’s pres at the bar. Dirty, muddy, haggard.

May 17th, Wolf Creek. I travel through places that didn’t exist 3 months ago. First there are tents, then houses, then 2 months later shops with women fiercely discussing the price of flour. I found this line by Thoreau. “This town too lies out”... At one point, he senses Warm’s shadow by his side.
We've seen each other before?
No I don’t think so.
You were in Myrtle Creek two days ago.
Yes I was, like many other folk.
Are you heading down to San Francisco?
No, just to Jacksonville.  21.
Work?
Yes, work. Warm is now sitting two tables away.
And you, San Francisco? Gold?
Yes, like many other folk. A beat. Warm looks at him with a strange smile. Morris is almost embarrassed.
May I tell you something, sir?
Of course.

Typically, when a man wishes another man good day, he smiles while facing the other person, but once he passes by, the smiles drops from his face. Not you. Your smile remains on your lips after you have turned away. Warm’s candor and good nature throw Morris for a loop.
(embarassed) Well I... I’ve hadn’t noticed... It’s common courtesy.
It’s not only that. You take a genuine pleasure in communing with others. Am I mistaken?
I honestly do not know. (a beat) Would you like to join me for lunch?
I'd have loved to, but I am a bit hard up at the moment.  22.
As my guest, of course.
The two men are having dinner. A beat.
And what takes you to Jacksonville?
Business to settle. I’m meeting two of my associates there.How are you making your way south?
I have a seat in a covered wagon.
How long do you think till you reach Frisco?

The question is not how long before I get there, the question is what state will I be in when I do. If I do. To be honest with you, my faith in my hosts is very limited. They've rifled through my belongings several times and every time I take out my money, their eyes are like daggers.
Mr Warm. You ought to not endanger yourself in that way. You have to be more careful than that
What other choice do I have?

head_text.subj: EXT PIONEER TOWN 03 / HORSE DEALER DAY

text: A corral. Horses, mules and oxen. The horse dealer shows Warm some mules. Morris examines t
50, horseshoes included.  23.
35 is for a mule!
40, with the saddle, bag and shoes.
Hey listen to me if you want to by a horse you pay the price for a horse. Morris examines the mare’s hooves.
You're never gonna sell this horse. Not at 50, not at 40... She’s a bad hip, anyone’d see that with an eye. 40! 40.
But...
Gentlemen I have found him. I have managed to make an acquaintance and have arranged to travel with him. If all goes well we should be in Jacksonville...
Morris and Warm are riding side by side, chatting. They l the slow covered wagons behind.
win seven days... I will try to hold him until your arrival and find a secluded place to hand him over.
A relay station on the trail, for horses and stagecoaches Eli finishes reading the message from Morris:
«Make haste. John Morris.»  24.
One good point for Morris, even if I don’t like the... “Make haste.” Who does that asshole think he is? He turns to the horse-dealer in charge of the place.
When did they pass through?
Four days ago.
Is there a faster way to Jacksonville, off trail?
Well, it’s rougher to go up the mountains but you’ll save a couple of days.
They climb switchbacks up a mountain road. A forest looms before them, like a dark green wall. Their silhouettes disappear behind the line of trees.

Eli is woken by groaning. He turns toward Charlie. He sta up and leans over him. Tears are flowing from Charlie’s closed eyes. He whimpers groans in his sleep. Eli feels moved by his brother’s pain. He wavers, then pu out his hand to wake him. Charlie’s eyes suddenly pop ope
Peek-a-boo ! Eli jumps up. Charlie bursts out laughing. He clutches his stomach. Eli looks peeved. Charlie imitat Eli.
Fool!  25.
I thought you were going to kiss me! The blankets shake as they laugh uncontrollably.
They ride, tiny among the tall trees. Their voices and hoofbeats echo among the trunks. After a beat:
The rain muddied it all up. I can’t see a thing. What do you think?

We must be able to pick up the trail somewhere. They split up. Eli rides alone, looking for the trail. He turns back fro time to time, but no longer sees his brother. He is overtaken by a feeling of dread. He spots some ruts, some hoof prints... He whistles:

Over here ! He continues onward and finds the remains of a wagon, an animal carcass... and human bones. He dismounts. The wagon has obviously been plundered. He kicks at some pathetic scraps. A piece of paper catches h eye. He unfolds it, wipes it clean and tries to make out writing. He hears Charlie arrive. He slips the paper into jacket and gets back on Tub.
They are riding, Charlie in front, Eli behind deciphers t letter he found among the debris.
“Dear Mother, I feel lonely and the days are long here. My horse has passed and he was a close friend. I think of your cooking and wonder what I’m doing here. I believe I will come home soon. (MORE )

I have almost 200 dollars in gold dust. It’s not the pile I'd hoped for, but good enough for now. The smell of smoke in still my nostrils and I haven’t had a laughed in such a long time. Mother! I think I will leave here very soon. With all my love, Your son”

Smoldering embers in the fire. Eli is asleep, wrapped in his patchwork quilt. He half- o his eyes and sees his brother by the light of the embers, gun across his lap. A fine watchman. He shuts his eyes, feeling reassured. Close on black. Open on extreme CU: A hairy spider climbs up Eli’s neck. reaches his neck. It remains there for a beat, as if to g its bearings. When Eli’s mouth opens, it disappears insid Close on black.

A starry sky. Morris walks up to the horses. Behind him, a few dozen fe away, there’s another campfire with a few prospectors hav dinner. Morris opens Warm’s small bag and discovers some clothes, uninteresting artefacts, a conversion table, a slide rule chemistry handbook and a few notebooks with “This noteboo belongs to H.K. Warm” written on the cover. He opens of those: pages filled with calculations and formulas. He hears footsteps behind him and goes back near the fire Warm comes up, he’s holding some bowls and cups of coffee
They are eating.  27.
I’ve only just noticed that’s the only bag you have? I guess you’re gonna have to buy gear when you get to San Francisco.
I don’t need equipment.
You're going to look for gold ina river without a shovel, a pail, a cradle...

This is the great challenge all prospectors face. How do I get what’s just beneath my feet? There’s only two solutions of course: hard labour and good luck. I’ve been working on a third solution for many years. One that is simpler, faster, more certain. And I think today I found it. Morris stares in disbelief.
You don’t believe me.
No offence, Warm, frankly I’m having a hard time.
You know it’s funny, people usually don't believe me, and then when they do, they want to kill me.
What is this idea? Morris looks at him. Warm smiles. After a beat.
Well I told you I’m a chemist. It’s the idea of a chemist, it’s a formula.
“Abracadabra”?  28.
No, a divining substance.
A divining substance you... you mix in the river water? Warm nods.
This formula... this diviner... call it what you may... as a man of science, have you ever tested it?
The sun has trouble piercing through forest and mist. Charlie is on his feet. Next to him, Eli’s blanket doesn' move. He gives his brother a kick.
Eli wake up !
I don’t feel good... Charlie lifts up the blanket. Eli is hunched up, shiverin His head has swollen to twice its size. It is a different color.
Oh shit what happened to your face? Eli answers inaudibly.
I don’t know.
It’s all swollen and your neck! You look like... one of those dogs, what is it, the... The Mastiff!
Fuck you! I’m sick.
All right sit up. Let me look at you. Eli opens his mouth. Charlie looks inside and makes a fac  29.
Got a gallon of blood sloshing around in there! Charlie helps him sit up.
You think you can sit in a saddle?
I don’t know, I’m freezing. Eli’s head bobs.

Pouring rain. An occasional flash of lightning lights up tree trunks. Charlie leads them on. Eli holds on, rocked and forth. Semi-unconscious, Eli hunches over Tub’s neck. The horse trips. Eli’s teeth clatter and he shouts in pain. Bloody trickles onto Tub’s neck. Charlie hands him a wad of tobacco.
Stick this between your teeth. It’ll stop them from chattering. We're going to have to hurry if we want to outrun the storm. He takes the reins of Eli’s horse.
You holding on? Eli grabs onto the saddle knob.

Charlie struggles to open an oilcloth, like a sail slappi in the wind. He stretches it between two trees then unfolds another on underneath... He lays Eli down on it and covers him with blankets. Eli shivers.
I’m tired, Charlie... He closes his eyes. Black.
Wind roars, rain patters. Open. Eli’s low-angle POV: In a sudden flash of lightning, shadow of a man’s face cuts out in the light of dawn.
There you are my sweeties.
Pa... Pa...
I’ve looked all over for you. The silhouette’s man chopping wood with an axe. We move in slowly, we hear choked breathing.
Pa?!
Come closer, let me take you in my arms.
No... No! 30. the We come nearer and find arms and legs on the chopping blo and his feet red with blood. Black.

Eli opens his eyes. He takes a moment to observe the trees: they slowly sway, water drips from their leaves, they straighten up. His he looks less swollen. He sticks a finger in his mouth, retches and spits out bl phlegm.  31.
You okay? A beat.

I think so. Charlie, naked, squats next to a dying fire, trying to wa up some beans. His clothes are stretched out around the f Eli comes to. A huge brown clump between their camp and t horses catches his eye: the corpse of a grizzly bear. He stands up.
What happened?
Well, this gentleman wandered into the camp last night. Eli goes over to look at the grizzly’s cadaver in the mud
He got your horse real good. He went right for him. Eli goes over to Tub, still shaking: The bear ripped away some of his nose. A damaged left eye under a bloody lid.
It’s the horses that woke me up. What a fucking night!
I had a dream about Pa’ last night. Charlie throws away the beans, stands up and gathers up h clothes.
Well that’s perfect ! I'm sick of this place. It reeks of death, everything is fucking soaked. Let’s go! 43 INT JACKSONVILLE MORRI’S ROOM DAY:
Morris washes his hands and face at the basin.  32. He dries himself off and surprises his reflection in the mirror. He looks at himself.
In front of the Motel, Morris asks a man for directions. TITLE: JACKSONVILLE OREGON.
Third house, on the right.
Thank you.
Morris takes a walk around. Once he gets away from the trail, things become quiet. He checks out passersby as if counting them. On the outskirts of town, behind a sort of hangar, he spo shack.
He pushes open the door: hay, not much light. Through the wood slats in the wall, the town, far enough away.
Morris opens the door to his room. 47 INT JACKSONVILLE HOTEL MORRIS’S ROOM DAY:
His saddle bags and knapsack are still on the floor. He p his knapsack on the bed, opens it...

Shit... He goes to the window and peers into the street. No one. heads to the door and opens it: Warm is on the landing, a pair of handcuffs dangling from hand and, in the other, a Colt aimed at Morris’s forehead  33.
Are you looking for this? Get back... Get back! He points to Morris and closes the door behind him.
What’s the matter? Are you not going to say “listen Hermann I can explain”? Huh? Warm throws the handcuff on the floor.
Pick that up, face that way, put it on your left hand. Morris obeys. The handcuff closes around his wrist.

Let me see your hand... Good, now the other one. Morris puts his hand behind his back. Just as Warm is abo to cuff him, he pulls out his left hand, spins around and punches him in the face. Warm goes flying backwards. The falls to the floor. Morris grabs it. When Warm tries to get up, Morris pistol-whips him. 48A INT JACKSONVILLE HOTEL MORRIS’S ROOM NIGHT:

Night has fallen. Warm is sitting bound and gagged on a chair. Morris is ly on the bed with his gun at his side. Blood rolls down Warm’s head. He moans. He moans harder. Morris understands and gets up.
(pointing to the gag) If I take it off, will you keep quiet? Warm nods. Morris removes the gag. Warm breathes. He look dismayed.
Are we waiting for your friends? No answer.  34.
How could you be so two-faced? What taught you such duplicity? Is it greed? I hadn’t noticed that in you... I really hadn't.
You keep quiet or I’1l put this back in.
You think they’11l kill me? They won’t kill me... Not right away. A beat. He looks at Morris.
What do you think your Commodore wants? He’s the one who tried to rob me in Oregon City. He’s after my Formula, my invention.
So what?
So your friends... Your friends are on their way here to torture me. To torture me, did you know that? Morris didn’t know that.
They’1l cut off my fingers, burn my feet, gouge out my eyes... They’1l torture me till I talk.
Morris, can I ask you something? ...Are you gonna watch? ...Are you gonna write it down in your book of adventures? Morris looks at him now.
Warm... I... He searches for the words, but cannot find them.
It’s this world... It’s an abomination.  35. Warm’s face is now turned toward the window. He doesn’t a anything.
He stopped talking, didn’t say another word. He watched the sun rise through the window. 48B INT JACKSONVILLE HOTEL MORRIS’S ROOM DAWN:

The sun is up. Warm his waking up. He notices his hands are free, the handcuffs are gone. He gets up and walks closer to Morris who’s sleeping on t bed. He pushes him gently. Morris wakes up with a start, in his hand. He sees Warm standing before him and lowers his gun. Morr slowly emerges. They look at each other for a moment, then, as he straigh up:
Let's go.
You don’t think you’re making a mistake?
Charlie on Nimble, at breakneck speed. Eli and Tub behind. Tub is galloping with his damaged hea down at his side, as if drowning.
A hilltop. A town below. Eli looks down at the town. Sitting behind him, Charlie h laid out a rag. He is cleaning and preparing his weapons assiduously.
How do we go about this Warm?
Like we usually do.  36.
Well usually there’s no Morris
Morris hands over Warm. We go some place quiet and finish the job. You done? Eli nods. Charlie stands up and gathers his effects.
We recognize Main Street Jacksonville and Smith’s hotel.. where Warm and Morris stayed. Eli and Charlie approach the hotel.
You go round back.

Eli gets off his horse and looks around behind the hotel: windows, gallery, roof... All of a sudden, a noise: Someone is trying to open an upstairs window. Eli takes out his gun. He is about to sh when Charlie's head pops out...
Christ, Charlie, I almost shot! Eli unlocks his gun. Charlie pops his head back out.
They’re not here!
Where are they?
They left, four days ago! Morris left a note. Shit!
They are in a saloon amid other customers. They both drin while Charlie reads Morris’letter out loud:  37.

“Dear gentlemen, I’m sorry to inform you that Hermann Kermit Warm has made a precipitate departure. He must have hopped a wagon train and left town. I am going after him as of today. Good luck. Sincerely. John Morris”

“Hermann Kermit Warm has made a precipitate departure”?!? Who the fuck is he kidding? Who the fuck is this pretentious asshole kidding?!? He grabs the letter and crumples it. He flings it to the floor and tramples it.
What now? Charlie finishes his glass and pours himself another.
We keep on. We said between Jacksonville and Mayfield, and we're only in Jacksonville. And God damn it, the job isn’t “Jacksonville” or “Mayfield”, the job is to kill Warm!
(pointing to the barman) Say it louder, I don’t think he heard.
(softer) Wherever the fuck Warm is, Mayfield or wherever, we go there and get it over with!
When will we be back home?
Once we’re done with the job, Eli. Eli picks up the letter and uncrumples it.
I get the feeling they’re farther and farther ahead of us. How long were we in that forest?  38.
Your spells and illnesses haven’t saved us any time, that’s for sure.
What do you mean, that it’s my fault?
Yeah, a little. Isn’t it?
You want to talk about your constant drunkenness? Didn’t it cost us any time? Charlie finishes his glass, slams a coin on the bar and leaves.
Days when you can’t even sit up in the saddle straight?? The other morning when you puked on yourself?... My spells! My ass! Eli follows him out.
Warm and Morris ride side by side, speaking like friends.
What we need to do is to put an end to all this barbarity. Put an end to all this violence, find a solution for it. By inventing a new society. A society...
Warm and Morris each sit to one side of the fire.
«+. where the relationships among men is governed by respect and the absence of profit. Thus a society without greed. Do you agree?  39.
What’s it have to do with your formula? You're looking for gold too, like everyone else.

For me the gold is just a stepping- stone. John I’m serious. To found a new society. One, one that will consecrate itself not to profit or gold, but its, its spiritual development, its own subsistence, nothing more, the education of its children...
And where do you intend to create this society?
Dallas, northern Texas. There are already many people waiting there. More are on the way from Europe. Warm take a sip. Morris remains silent. Troubled. A beat.
Well I can see I’ve lost you... John?

One evening, you told me about your father that you left him because there was no place for you. As for me all I can say is that I left my family out of hatred and that my father was the person I despised most in this world I...despised everything about him. I sincerely thought I had been freed of all that until tonight, listening to you, what do I realize? That most of the things that I thought I’d been doing, these past years, freely, the opinions that I thought I had of my own volition, were in fact dictated by my hatred towards that man.  40.
I'm 35 years old and my life is like an empty cylinder. Black.
Further south, in a relay station. Morris is writing a letter.

“My dear solicitor, my dear friend, After much thought, I’ve changed my mind about the measures concerning my finances related to you in my last letter. I accept my father’s inheritance and ask you to wire 3,000 dollars to the Project Bank in San Francisco. Finally, I will not be in Washington until next year. I send you my friendship and I shake your hand. Yours, John Morris.” John Morris joins Warm, sitting on the ground, drawing in of his notebooks. Morris looks at him for a moment. He ha him the notebook, we can see an intricate drawing mixing letter W and M.
It’s us. W & M, Warm and Morris. Our company’s insignia. What do you think? He smiles and hands him back the notebook.
I like it.

The brothers walk through Mayfield. The town is just as d and muddy. On either side of Main Street, families wander among tent and wagons. All the signs bear the name Mayfield: Mayfiel Supplies, Mayfield General Store, Mayfield Gold...  41.
You think this man came here because it’s called Mayfield or they started calling that once he got there?
Maybe it all belongs to him.
They sure like that name. Charlie heads for the saloon. Eli follows as best he can.
The saloon is crowded. The Sisters are at the bar. The bartender comes. Charlie goes to speak to him, but suddenly feels exhausted and gives up.
(to the barman) Hello, we're looking for a man named Warm. Short, dark skinned... We think he passed through here a few days ago.
I can’t help you, mister. He starts to leave but Charlie grabs onto his sleeve.
No ? What about a tall brown haired man of forty...
I don’t know, mister. I don’t get mixed up in it
“Oh You don’t get mixed up in it do you?” Give us some whiskey.
Normal or Mayfield‘s?
Normal. Bottle, two glasses.
You're looking for someone?  42. A deep voice. Charlie turns to face Mayfield, a middle-ag woman with a magnetic gaze and a tough look on her face.
Because usually I’m the one people ask for news in this town.
And who are you?
Mayfield. Charlie turns around to his brother.
Ah! The great man himself! Behind them, the bartender puts the bottle down and pours them drinks.
My brother and I are looking for a man named Hermann Warm. Short, dark skinned? Probably passed through fiveor six days ago?
Warm?... No, I don’t recall. Charlie finishes his glass, making a noise with his tongu From the one shot, he is already feeling happier.
Is this man a friend of yours? Eli starts to answer but Charlie beats him to it.
He ran out on a debt to our employer, The Commodore, in Oregon City. Charlie watches for an effect. And the woman has tensed t hear the Commodore’s name.
We are the Sisters brothers. And to his satisfaction, Mayfield is duly unsettled. Eli, the other hand, is put off by this braggadocio.  43.

Good to meet you men. You planning on staying long? Eli stares at his teeth, chomping at his cigar. Charlie t around and looks at the clientele. A group of girls is co down a staircase. His shoulders straighten up.
Well that depends...
(sternly) We'll be leaving first thing. Charlie drains his glass. His eyes are glazed from booze.
The hotel is dilapidated, the staircase narrow. Eli and Charlie carry their bags up.
Why the hell you keep telling everyone your life story? The Commodore, the Sisters brothers...
Don’t you see how honored that woman was to put us up? And besides, I like to know if our reputation has preceded us. Unlike you, brother, I’m proud of what I do. Eli sighs.
What does that mean?
It means it’s going to be the same as usual: you'll drink like a fish tonight and be sick as a dog tomorrow...
You're forgetting something: I’m going to fuck like a rabbit!
Another day up our ass.
Charlie runs Charlie runs up the stairs. We hear women’s laughter.
Don’t pay attention to him, he’s crabby, he’s old!

Charlie sits at a table, drinking. He has a cheap whore o his lap, and his hand under another one’s skirt. She gigg into his shoulder. Eli is at the bar, embarrassed. He looks away. Mayfield i bit farther off, in discussion with a group of trappers. Behind them, Eli notices a girl by the piano. They exchan glances. Mayfield waves to the barman, who brings another bottle.S comes over and starts to pour Charlie a drink. Eli’s hand stops her.
He can pour his own liquor.
Sure thing!

Hey look who’s awake? Look at that. Big knife with the big boy. Where are you going?! Hey have you noticed how many raccoons there are in this town? Like dead raccoons? It’s a shitty town to be a raccoon in! Mayfield puts the bottle back down.Eli goes over to the g near the piano. She forces a smile. He whispers into her ear.
How much just to talk?
They are sitting on the bed in a narrow room. Far apart. Hands in their laps. A moment of embarrassment.  45.
We can act like you’re giving me this shawl and you consider it a valuable object. You understand? With a kind word. She takes the shawl and tries to think of something to sa She smiles.
Here. Eli gives it back, frustrated.
No. With a kind, huh....
What... I don’t know what...
Simple words: « I thought it might get cold...»
I thought...
I’m leaving and you're giving me this.
I... I thought it might get cold... He encourages her to improvise but she just repeats what said, handing him the shawl.
This shawl...
“,..is a little piece of me that’s traveling with you.”
This shawl is a little piece of me...
(frustrated) You have to... with your eyes, you have to look at it! Like it means something.  46. The woman obeys, and speaks softly.
This shawl is like a little part of me is traveling with you... I puta drop of my perfume on it.
(softer) Good. Now, can I steal a kiss from you? She closes her eyes to get kissed.
Yes.
No, you say that. Eli’s lips touch hers. She takes his hand and suddenly tu away.
Are you not well? No answer. He sees a tear roll down her cheek.
Did I hurt you?
No, not at all... you’re just very kind and gentle, and I’m not used to it. Please let me go.
But... I’1l pay. He grabs onto her arm.
I need to go, please. She runs to the door, starts to open it, turns back aroun
Be careful.
About what? The woman mouths something, pointing down. Eli reads her lips: “May-field!”  47.

Eli has gathered their belongings. He walks around the gallery of the saloon, hugging the walls. Down below, in dark corner, he sees Mayfield speaking with a group of suspicious-looking trappers. He climbs the stairs, passes by some whores in a hallway. pushes open a door, then another. He sees men on top of women, women straddling men.
Charlie..? Charlie...? Another door... Eli finds Charlie slumped on a sofa, in a narrow red cabi from which a half-dressed whore exits quickly. Charlie, almost passed-out, is slumped on a sofa.
There you are! Charlie. Charlie! You have to wake up. They’re coming. You get up!
I don’t want to.
You get up! Mom says, Get up! Get up!
Ok...
Put your boots on. Come on. Hey, Charlie, Charlie. Can you shoot, can you shoot? Eli puts Charlie’s boots on. Charlie’s head wobbles, with stupid grin.
I’m not at my best...
Don’t you puke on me. The brothers reach the stables.  Charlie finishes getting dressed as best he can, while readies the horses as quick as he can. When a voice surprises them:
Getting ready to leave Mayfield? Eli stops dead. The four trappers are there. 48. Eli Eli looks at Charlie, hung over, his head burrowed in his horse’s mane. He turns to the trappers:
Alright. Let’s just calm down. We have money. Just tell us what Mayfield is paying you.
I don’t think you’re going to live long enough to find that out.
It’s funny that there’s so many few words to describe things here in Mayfield. Charlie, who was out of it till now, slowly lets go of Ni and seems to wake up.
Mayfield’s whiskey and Mayfield’s hotel, Mayfield’s Fucking Mayfield...
Please let me handle this. Look...
Mayfield’s racoon, Mayfield’s Horses... Eli is worried to see Charlie wobbling.
Why don’t you just tell us how much you want?
No, Eli, it’s not about money... it’s about reputation. (MORE )
Being the guys that killed the Sisters brothers. Eli sees that something has changed in his brother’s eyes feels reassured.
You shut up now.

Prestige. Charlie throws up. A beat. The trappers look at him in disgust. And in a flash, the brothers draw simultaneously. Their cylinders spin, their barrels spit fire, flames light up barn... Three trappers go flying into the hay... The four runs out of the barn and tries to escape... Charlie whistles to Eli, who tosses him another gun, with even glancing at him... Charlie catches it and, at the same time, aims and fires. 63 INT MAYFIELD’S OFFICE NIGHT: Mayfield speaks expressionlessly. A rivulet of blood runs down from her forehead and drips off the tip of her nose.

... Warm said he needed an investor for some prospecting scheme. I couldn’t make heads or tails of his story. I thought he was a clown, but when I saw Morris, I thought... if the Commodore’s interested, it might be worthwhile.
Did Morris leave a letter for us?
No. He was just traveling with Warm.
Really? And why did you want to kill us?  50. Mayfield hesitates. Charlie raises the butt of his revolv
I'll repeat that, then I’1l strike.
When I realized Warm had something of value, I sent some guys after them to bring him back.
So now there’s more men on Warm’s tail?
Yes. Charlie raises the butt of his revolver.

All right, Mayfield, you’re not going to like what comes next, but it’s the price to pay when you mess for messing with our buisness. Open your safe. Mayfield’s face freezes. She slowly shakes her head.
No. Never.

64 INT. MAYFIELD’S OFFICE NIGHT: Later. Charlie is emptying a safe: bills, pieces of gold, pouche gold dust. The office has been turned upside down. Mayfield’s body l in the middle, in a puddle of blood.
Loaded down with their plunder, they see half the town outside, awoken by the gunfight.A group of poor people, s in nightclothes.  51.
(softly) Think we should say something to them? The silent crowd separates to let them through. Charlie l at the curious townspeople, then up at Eli.
After a series of dramatic events that she only had herself to blame for... Mayfield is dead!
No, not like that. Don’t you have anything more positive? Charlie mounts Nimble.
My brother and I have some good news for you people! You can change the name of your fucking town! They spur their horses and gallop away. Behind them, a cr of famished people invades the saloon.
Their saddlebags, knapsacks and pockets are stuffed with bills, coins and gold dust. The horses gallop.
Fifty yards off the trail, on a hillside, the brothers fi digging a hole behind trees and rocks.
Anyway, now we know one thing for sure. We know Morris has joined the enemy.
I never liked that gentleman, but I must say this is the icing on the cake.  52.
Warm have that’s so interesting? The Commodore sends men after him, Mayfield sends men after him, and now Morris falls into him. What does he have?
He has a formula. It’s a chemical product. Supposedly, you pour it in the river, it lights up all the gold, and you just bend down to pick it up.
You don’t believe that stuff Charlie, come on! We’ve seen our fair share of hucksters with miracle products...
Yes but the Commodore seemed to believe in this one.
Why didn’t you tell me about it before?
I had orders not to. In the hole, they put their treasures, wrapped in oilskin
Anything else you’re hiding from me? Charlie looks embarrassed.
The Commodore’s orders are clear- cut: before we kill Warm, we are to extract from him by whatever violent means necessary the recipe for his formula.
In lay terms: torture him?
More or less.
The brothers ride side by side, through plains and rivers
How far ahead do you think Mayfield’s guys got?
Well if they’re as stupid as the last guys we killed, I'd say we're about even.
I like it here. There’s a fortuitous energy.
What the hell is a “fortuitous energy”?
You feel it, dummy!
The path is climbing up through short vegetation.
You know what, brother? I don’t think you and I have ever gone so far.
You mean between us, in our conversation?

What are you talking about? I meant in a straight line. You and I have never gone so far in a straight line! The brothers can hear a distant, continuous rumbling. All a sudden, here is it, wide and endless: the ocean. They put their hands on their hats so they won't fly and at the water. It’s obvious they’ve never seen something l it.  54.
At times, waves come crash on the horses’ hooves. The brothers ride through the beach. There’s no one to be see for miles and miles.
There are prints on the sand now - men, animals, carriage and sometimes a few objects people have left on the way: trunks, furniture, a bed...
They ride up a street on horseback, into the fray: tents up in the lanes, trappers, chained slaves, Chinese famili sleeping in the streets.
(eyes glittering, almost moved) Goddamn, this place is Babylon! When they look up, they can see three-floor brick houses brightly-lit windows.
You know, when we find Warm, it won't be worth looking for a quiet spot, there isn’t one in this whole place!
More importantly nobody will care. We can kill anyone we want here. Fuck, everyone’s mind is focused on something else.

Elsewhere. They leave their saddles at a stable and continue on foot their gear propped on their shoulders. In front of them, they suddenly spot a warm and hospitabl light, the lights of a “grand hotel”, The Golden Pearl.  55. They look inside through a window. Like two kids in front a Christmas window display.
A valet precedes them through an upstairs corridor with a kerosene lamp. He points to a door:
That’s the water-closet in there... ++. and then another door...
..-that’s the bathroom, with hot water. «.. and yet another door.

And here is your room. He opens the door, enters and begins to turn on the lamps The room appears: a red velvet bijou, gold tassels, braid pompoms, beds in rococo copper... They've never seen anything like it before.

Red as a lobster and wrapped in a towel, Eli has just ste out of a hot bath. He looks curiously at the dangling cha with a wood knob. He hesitates, pulls on it, and to his surprise a torrent of water gushes into the toilet bowl.
Charlie, come and look at this! He walks out.
A restaurant in the same style as the rooms: European overkill. The two brothers have no clue how to behave, or what to d with all the silverware set before them.
Eli and Charlie are eating and drinking. Especially Charl
A bit of comfort in uncertain times. Eli nods. A Beat.
You know I was thinking... We could just go back to Oregon City and say we couldn’t find them.
And tell what to the Commodore?

The truth: Morris ran off with Warm. Destination unknown. Can’t be expected to find them without a single clue to guide us. And... (lower) We don’t even know if Mayfield’s men have already found them...
Ok, what are you getting at, brother? Eli lowers his voice and starts in:
Between what we made in Mayfield, what we have at home and the rest, we have enough to ditch the Commodore for good.
And why would we do that?
Didn't you ever think of stopping?
And do what?
I don’t know (he hesitates) We could open a store together.  57.
What store?
Look, we've had a good long run, we're still alive, we’ve a bit of our youth left. It’s a chance to get out. Charlie turns beet-red. Alcohol mixed with pent-up anger.
A store? A way out? Fucking nonsense! What is this bullshit? He is about to knock over the table or slap Eli who stare him without backing down.
...Well, we’ve established that you want to quit, so quit! Charlie finishes his glass and takes a deep breath. He st eating again. After a beat:
Meaning what? That if I stop, you’d continue?
Of course I’d continue. I'd just need a new partner. Rex asked for work in the past...
Rex? Rex is just a talking dog.
He is obedient like a dog. I could ask Sanchez. Eli is stunned.
Sanchez...? You would really trust Sanchez and that idiot Rex to protect you? Charlie looks him eye to eye.  58.

Because you protect me? Is that what you have to tell yourself to stay “nice guy Eli”? But WE are the Sisters brothers. The Sisters brothers, Eli you and me! Charlie straightens up and starts searching his pockets f money.

You've made your decision, and it’s fine by me. It will be welcome news to he Commodore also. We'll finish this job, then part ways. He throws a few bills on the table. Moved, Eli pays no attention and continues.
Why do you say it like that? "We'll part ways"?
How do you want me to say it? If I stay with the Commodore and you open your store...
So you're saying we won’t see each other any more?
Yes, when I come into town. Whenever I need a shirt, or some underthings... Eli watches Charlie light a cigar and stand up as if noth were the matter.

Do you need to speak to me so rudely? To choose those words? To keep the level of the conversation so low. Is it because you're drunk? Charlie looks at his brother and slaps him. Instinctively, Eli’s hand grips the butt of his revolver. Customers around them freeze and watch Charlie put on his and leave the restaurant with the face and gait of a drun man.  59.

head_text.subj: INT GOLDEN PEARL HOTEL ROOM NIGHT

text: Fully clothed, Eli is lying on the bed in the dark, gaudy room. He stares at the shadows from the street played out red velvet walls and the ceiling. Charlie’s bags and clothes are still sitting on his bed. Eli stands up and starts packing.
Eli is about to mount Tub when:
Hey, brother! He turns around. Charlie is all rosy and dapper.
What are you doing here? Eli is speechless. Charlie continues, matter-of-factly.
I've got some great fucking news, brother. I know where they are! What do you say to that? Eli look at him without answering.
Did you hear me?
Yes.
You don’t even care? What’s wrong with you?
Don’t you remember what happened last night?
Yes. And?
Don’t you remember that you hit me? Charlie pretends to try to remember.
Stop pretending and spare me the « I don‘t remember » routine. You hit me in public Charlie, so as sure as you’re looking at me right now, I’m leaving. Charlie grabs Tub’s bridle.

All right, what do you want? This is about slapping each other, isn’t it? I slap you, you slap me back and we’re even. So go on, hit me. Hit me, I said. 60. Before he can even give Eli his cheek, he receives a stun that sends him flying backwards.
Jesus fucking Christ! Are you out of your goddamned mind? I gave you a slap, and you whack me with a fucking shovel!
See? You do remember! Charlie gets back up, rubbing his cheek.

(facing camera) This morning I woke up in a whorehouse and figured I might as well stop by the claims office. So I went and asked if a certain Herman Kermitt Warm had recently staked a claim. Nothing! I was about to give up, when boom, it hit me. I asked if there was anything in the name of John Morris... and there: American River, Folson Lake... bingo! Now we know where they're heading.
CU: a crude map of American River. Eli holds the map. He tries to find his bearings in the landscape.
They ride on. First, a delta...

head_text.subj: 78B EXT AMERICAN RIVER PROSPECTORS TRAIL DAY

text: .+. They ride the river upstream... They pass by men on f with mules, loaded down with gear...

head_text.subj: 78C EXT AMERICAN RIVER PROSPECTORS TRAIL DAY

text: ... There are now prospectors at work on each of the riverbanks. Charlie takes a pair of binoculars, peers at camps, the faces...
I'd like to see how they go about it.
Oh another idea for a career change? First selling shirts, now prospecting? I’m gonna go on ahead, you do as you please.

head_text.subj: 78D EXT AMERICAN RIVER PROSPECTORS TRAIL DAY

text: ... Tub’s eye has turned white and is surrounded by pus. shoos away flies and tries to clean the wound. The horse shudders and peels.
Now it’s all uphill. Tub is breathing hard. He drools spi and blood. His eye is now white, pus oozing around it. A horse of the Apocalypse.
Charlie calls out to a prospector below:
Folsom Lake? The prospectors point upstream.
How far?  62.
A day ! He rides back to Eli.
We'll be there tomorrow.
Encampment. Remains of a fire. Under the covers, Charlie already asleep. Eli tries to make Tub drink. He encourage him, speaking softly.

Come on Tub. Eat some grass. Oh Tub, I’m sorry my friend. Tub’s white eye almost glows in the dark. He takes the red shawl from his saddlebags. He carefully folds it into a pillow, breathes in its fragrance and goe bed. He pulls up his blanket and begins to masturbate.
Warm binocular POV: The silhouette of the sister brother, sleeping next to the fire.
You think it’s them?
Yes. They got here faster than I thought.

The brothers are asleep. The sound of the river below, the horses. Another noise. Eli opens his eyes: a silhouette towers over him... Nearby, Charlie straightens up... the toe of a boot viole knocks him flat. Black. A blurry vision. Voices of men heard from afar:  63.
No!.. No, not like this! Warm joins Morris.
Not like what?
This is no way to kill people.
We have to kill them, Hermann! We kill them, bury them, no one finds them. By the time it dawns on the Commodore, we’ll be far gone.
We don’t work for the Commodore anymore!
Then what are you doing here? Warm and Morris turn around. Eli, in a daze, has stood up.

We...We don’t work for him anymore. 82 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT DAY Charlie and Eli ground. Charlie Contrary to the seems strangely are handcuffed, sitting together on the has a nasty black and blue mark on his cheek. specifics of their current situation, Charlie happy:
And it just came out?!?
~-. Yes.

You're a genius, Eli, a goddamn genius! How did that pop into your head? Just out of the blue? He nods, evasively. Warm and Morris have set up camp on a wide strip of pebbles in the middle of the river.  64. Two tents, some gear, barrels, oilskin tarpaulins protect their supplies. The horses are tied up on the banks. They watch Warm and Morris gather the gear they need, loa the animals. Charlie yells at them:

Hey, Morris, what you gonna do with us? Ask us to run and shoot us like rabbits? Dump us in the forest? Charlie sniggers, Morris barely looks back. 83 INT MORRIS’S TENT DAY: Morris is sitting at a small wood table, studying a map. walks into the tent, Morris doesn’t turn around.
What are we going to do about them?

We leave them here. They’1l end up killing each other or getting eaten alive... I couldn’t care less. We take the horses and the mules, we extract what we can from the river one last time and then we leave here without ever coming back.
And abandon all our gear?
We'll travel light, ride up to Sacramento, buy more gear, and ride up the river from there. Suddenly, from further down the hill:
Anyone there? 84 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT DAY:
Anyone there? Can you hear me? Morris takes a few steps forward.  65.
Yes, what do you want? Another silhouette appears in the background.
We're working the river downstream. We’re running out of supplies. You’ve got any for sale? Warm joins Morris.
They don’t look like prospectors.
They’re not prospectors.
I didn’t hear your answer.
(To the man) Because I didn’t give one. Don’t you take one step closer! (to Warm) We're going to have to fight, Hermann. Are your guns loaded?
Yes, I think so. The silhouettes are creeping closer.

Well take it out goddammit ! (to the man) I told you not to move and I won’t tell you again! We have nothing to sell. Go back to where you came from! The man comes towards them. Morris shoots. The others sho right back. Flames, ricocheting bullets. Behind them, the brothers shield themselves as best they can.
Hey, what the hell? Do something! Don’t leave us here! A bullet ricochets near Warm, who jumps away.
Hermann! Hermann?  66.
(reassuringly) I’m okay, I’m okay.
Let us help you, Warm! Another volley of bullets.

Give us the keys you fucking idiots! You don’t stand a fucking chance, come on! Warm and Morris look at each other. They hesitate. 85 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT DAY: The four men are hiding behind boulders. The brothers che the weapons that have been returned to them.
You think it’s Mayfield’s men?
Sure looks like them. Charlie signals Warm and Morris to stop shooting. He stan up, using his hands as a megaphone:

Hey guys, before things sour, we've got some news for you: Mayfield is dead! You'll never get paid! Do you think this is really worth it? A beat, as if a discussion were going on over there. Then more gunfire. Charlie makes his way to Warm and Morris, b busy shooting.

(To Morris and Warm) As long as you can see us, you shoot at them like crazy. We make it to the other side and you can’t see us anymore, stop shooting. Get it? Agreement.  67. The brothers come out of hiding and move along, each to o side of the river. Warm and Morris fire. When the brother vanish into the forest, they stop shooting. Suddenly, the sounds of long 45 caliber flames pierce the day. We hear screams... then nothing. Eli reappears, dragging his feet, as if coming back from chore. Whena trapper arises from behind a thicket. Morris cocks revolver and shoots in a hurry. The trapper collapses revealing Charlie, his arm outstretched, his gun still smoking. The two men face each other. Frozen. And then slowly lowe their arms. A moment of unease. 86 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT NIGHT: They sit around the fire in heavy silence. They pass arou jug of liquor. Sizing one another up, eyeing one other. Eli notices that John Morris is scratching his legs. Hermann Warm clears his throat, then:
If Morris agrees to it, this is what I suggest. You two keep half of what you pull from the river, with the remaining half going to the Company.
The Company being you and Morris?
Yes, well, no... not exactly. The Company is our phalanstery project.
Phalan-what?
Phalanstery...
.--A community we’re founding, in Texas. (MORE )
An ideal living space, ruled by the laws of true democracy and sharing.
Whatever you say.
Does something bother you?
That's your business.
So we agree: half of what you extract?
Fine with me.
Me too. His eyes turn to Morris.
Excellent. Morris? After a beat.
Don’t ask my opinion. I don’t agree with what’s going on here. I’m still in, of course, but I remain on my guard.
Why don’t you look at me when you say that? Morris gets up.
Look at me, you son of a bitch!
Gentlemen! Morris turns to Charlie.
I’m looking at you, Charlie Sisters. Do you want me to tell you what I see?  69.
That’s enough! Eli holds back Charlie.
Please... The tension decrease.
I’m going to sleep.
Do your legs still hurt?
I’m all right. Goodnight, Hermann. They watch him wander off towards one of the tents.
He going to have to change. Warm gives a resigned shrug of the shoulders.

He doesn’t trust you and you can’t blame him. He’ll change. We all have to. We don’t have any other choice. His eyes are on them, a clear gaze, frank and disarmingly innocent. He scratches his legs nervously. Under the bott of his pants, the brothers make out red skin that is star to blister.
It's the Formula. It is very caustic in its purest form. I thought diluting it would make it harmless, but I was wrong. Next time, we'll have to grease our skins beforehand... He gets up.
Have you already prospected?
Two days ago.  70.
Did it work?

Better than I ever imagined. He walks away. 87 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT DAY: Early morning. Eli washes at the river. A little further he sees Morris brushing his teeth. He waves. Morris barel reacts. Off to one side, Charlie sits on the river bank, watches from afar.

head_text.subj: EXT MOUNTAIN FOREST RIVER BANK DAY

text: The horses, men and loaded mules make their way along the mountainside. Warm and Morris check the river’s flow. The brothers follow, pulling the mules. Charlie still wea the trapper’s hat. Ahead of them, Warm points to the river below. They come closer and discover a spot where the current sl down and the river bed widens. A landscape like before th birth of the world. 89 EXT WARM’S ENCAMPMENT DAY : They cut the branches on a tree they just felled. A mule pulls a trunk into the middle of the river. Bare-chested, the men cut branches and carry rocks... The work up to their waists in water. The dam is starting to take shape. Warm crosses the damme river to gauge its depth. With a knife, he scrapes the boulders in certain spots. He examines the samples with a jeweler's magnifying glass. Very tight shot: striations in the rock, shimmers of quar golden reflections.  71.
The sun is beating down. The men nap in the shade of the trees. Just the sound of insects and the river.

A new camp has been set up below at the foot of one of th riverbanks. Eli and Charlie finish setting up tents when they hear hoofbeats. They look back. Warm and Morris arrive with a straining under three barrels. The brothers watch the con pass by: it is obviously the Formula. Eli sees his brother’s eyes light up.
All four sit around a fire to finish their supper.
Who wants to stand guard tonight?
That’s our job, isn’t it?

Wearing his trapper's hat, Charlie sits up on a rock that towers over the river. After a while, he hears laughter down in the valley. He straightens up and sees the three others drinking and laughing, gathered around the fire. .
What are you doing?
We can’t sleep!
What’s the point of me being on guard, if you all don’t go to sleep?  72.
Charlie, why don’t you come down and join us? It’1ll do you good.
Come on. Come on, there’s no point. We're not going to sleep !

head_text.subj: EXT RIVER BANK NEW ENCAMPMENT DAWN

text: The four of them have their feet in the water. They guzzl booze. They rarely speak,smoking cigarettes and watching sunrise.
Morris is swimming in the translucent river. Charlie sits the riverbank, mocking look on his face.
Do you really believe in that two- bit ideal society nonsense?
What do you want me to say?
I don’t know but I say that a guy with a little bit of smarts has to realize that it sounds like solid gold bullshit.
Why do you think I’m here?
Like us. For the gold.
Sure, the gold, but what do you do with it?
Spend it, obviously!
You really think you'll have time to? With all the corpses you've left behind, the Commodore, your famous drunkenness... (MORE )
And if your pockets are full to boot, something tells me you won't be living to a ripe old age.
And would your ideal society make a difference?
I can’t say for you, but for me, yes. Charlie thinks.
Or else it’s a scam. A trap for suckers. Is that it?... Morris gestures that he has heard enough.
Let me tell you something, John Morris: you are one goddamned arrogant asshole.
Let me tell you something, Charlie Sisters: I couldn’t care less about what you think... that is to say, if you think.
Eli goes to check the horses. They are all there, except Tub. A piece of old rope dangles where he had been attach Eli whistles, looks everywhere.

He notices some blood on a bush. More, a little further on. Then hoof prints on the ground...He reaches the edge of a landslide. At the bottom of the ravine, Tub, motionless on his back, hoofs up. Eli looks at him, saddened.
Eli is sitting on the riverbank, looking at the reflectio the sun in water, at the jumping trout.
What are you doing here? Eli turns around to see Warm coming towards him.
Nothing much.
I’m heading up to the dam to see if the water has settled.
They are walking. At the bend, they see the dam where Mor and Charlie are working and talking.
See that?
Yeah, I get the impression Charlie is changing...
You mean he’s not going to try to kill us anymore?
It’s a little strange talking about this with you, isn’t it?

It’s Better facing up to things. You know, one day I asked Morris how he ended up working for aman like the Commodore. He said something along the lines of... the desire to break away from his family, to live an adventure. Honest enough. How about you? How did you end up here? Eli smiles.
Does my question bother you?

No, no, it’s just a long story. Charlie was always violent. When he got into a fight, it usually would end badly. And when you kill a man, you end up with his father, his brother or his friends on your tail, and you have to start all over again. One thing leads to another and I had to help him. He’s my brother. 75. They walk in silence. At one point, Eli makes a face. He his hand to his heart. He is dizzy.
You all right? Eli shakes his head. His hand looks for something to against. Warm helps him.
Must be the heat. We’ll sit here a moment and it will pass.
I’m sorry... I lost my horse... He died, I mean... Tub is dead... He was a middling horse, but... I didn’t think it to affect me like this...
When we were kids, Charlie killed our father. A beat.
I’m the older one. I should have done it.
Do you regret that?
Yes...‘cause after that, Charlie was never the same. lean  76.
Morning. Charlie sits on a rock, bare-chested. Eli is cut his hair. A beat.
That was a very pleasant day, don’t you think?
You get on well with Warm?
And you with Morris?
What did you talk about?
About us, about the Commodore... About Pa. He’s an easy man to talk to.
Tell me, what do you think the Commodore will do when he sees we're not coming back?
He’1ll send men after us. We’1ll have to get rid of them. And the ones after, and all the others he sends on our trail.
And then?
And then, sooner or later, to put an end to it, we’ll have to kill the Commodore... Eli does a double take. He considers the possibility.
Imagine we manage to kill the Commodore. What next? Charlie doesn’t answer. Eli hesitates, then:
You take his place?  77.
Are you taking the Commodore's place? Charlie looks at him.
How long have you been thinking about it? Charlie smiles, giving a small, mysterious shrug of the shoulders.

They cover their legs with grease, they pour the solution into smaller buckets. Warm and Morris exchange a look of hope. Warm looks straight to the lens. The smile on his face is hard to read: an ambiguous mixture of worry and excitemen

In the moonlight, the dammed up water looks like a black mirror. Charlie and Eli are on the riverbank, next to one of the barrels. Morris is standing on the top of the beavers’ da with a long branch. Warm, also with a branch, is standing the other side of the river.

Once you’ve emptied the solution, Morris and I will agitate the water to increase the field of illumination. Now once the formula starts to activate, grab your buckets and get to work! Not a moment to lose. Charlie and Eli lift the barrel and enter the water. They pour out the dense, viscous formula. The odor disgusts th Warm and Morris hurry to stir the water with their branch dispersing the solution. Charlie and Eli retreat to the riverbank, coughing.  78. They whack their branches on the water even harder, until Warm motions them to stop. The brothers wait on the bank. Still nothing.
What’s going on, Warm?

Just wait. The four men stare at the black water, waiting. Suddenly, a glow, then another, then... the river lights The four men rush in with their buckets: Warm and Morris under the dam, Charlie and Eli on the other side. Innumerable tiny gold nuggets, now dots of light, as clea stars in the sky. The four men work the river as fast as they can. All we c hear is the clanking of the nuggets falling into the buck The leafy trees look like a vault of gold overhead. Eli stops a moment to watch the three men working. Their faces are lit by the river. They all smile. A breeze play with their hair. Eli smiles too and goes back to work. Then the glow dies down as quickly as it appeared. Slowly the leafy vault darkens. Eli heads back to the bank, crying and coughing. He sees Charlie banging away at the cover of another barrel.
What are you doing?
We'll dump it all in! Warm sees him from the other bank.

Leave off! Eli, stop him! Charlie lifts the barrel. He takes a few steps. He loses balance and falls. Thick liquid pours out of the barrel a trickles onto his right hand, immediately attacking his s The loose barrel rolls down to the river, where the formu spreads in viscous filaments.  79. Blisters appear on Charlie’s forearm. They swell and pop a toad’s throat. He holds back a shriek of pain.

Charlie? Behind him, the river shines again in the barrel’s wake. Morris and Warm run across the dam. Morris trips. Eli see him fall into the water and disappear. He holds his breat Morris’s face resurfaces. He screams. Eli sees Warm put down his bucket and immediately darts u
No, Hermann, no! But Warm jumps in and disappears, like Morris.

The water is black. Warm resurfaces, holding up Morris. T cough, spit, gasp for breath. They collapse onto the sand 101B EXT WARM’S CAMP DAWN: Day breaks slowly over a landscape that has lost its colo Dead beavers and fish wash up onto the gravel. On the riverbank, Morris is dying. A groan more painful than the others makes him turn his h Morris is looking at him. His face is horribly burnt, his lips quiver as if trying to speak. Charlie knows what he is begging for. He stands up and fi a belt with weapons. He grabs one as best he can with his left-hand fingers that still work. He tosses the revolver to Morris, and then kicks it close his hand. 102A INT WARM AND MORRIS’S TENT. DAY:
Eli goes inside Warm’s tent. Face ravaged by blisters. Milky eyes bulging out. Heavy breathing.  80.
Hermann? Can I do something for you?
Morris? Is that you? Eli starts to clarify, but...
Yes, it’s me.
Oh, John! Where did you disappear to?
I was getting some firewood.
John, I feel I have known you a long time. I’m sorry you died before me. I wanted to help you. I wanted to be your friend.

You are my friend, Hermann. Warm retches. His last sigh sounds like paper crumpling. As Eli inches closer to Warm, a gunshot rings out. Eli st straight. 102B EXT WARM AND MORRIS’S TENT. DAY: Eli comes out of the tent. Charlie looks at him. By his side, Morris, dead, holding the revolver against h chest. 103 EXT WARM AND MORRIS’S TENT. DAY: Eli packs their bags to leave. He brings the results of t night’s collection: a bucket two-thirds full of nuggets. He manages to fit their treasure into Warm and Morris’ horse’s saddlebags. Charlie is too weak and ill. He stays under the covers.  81. 104 INT MORRIS’ TENT. DAY: Eli gathers Morris' things. On a crate by the bed, he discovers a hardback notebook w a title on its cover: "Adventure diary". The pages are blackened with cramped, regular writing. El feels a presence behind him. He leaves the tent.

I must confess that the very happiest moments of my life have been spent in the wilderness of the far west with the plentiful supply of dry pine logs on the fire. I would not... I would sit cross legged enjoying the genial warmth and watch the blue smoke as it curled upwards.
The brothers walk down the river.
Scarcely did I ever wish to change such hours of freedom for all the luxuries of civilized life.
In the steep passes, Eli has to tie Charlie to his back. ordeal.

Eli hears a scream from behind. Charlie has fallen from h horse. Eli rushes over. 107 EXT CRANE’S TOWN DAY: There are houses at the end of the road. 108A INT DOCTOR CRANE’S PRACTICE/OPERATING ROOM DAY A black forearm falls to the floor with a thud. Eli picks up and places it in the bucket nearby.  82. Doctor Crane cauterizes and bandages the stump. Charlie is still asleep on the operating table. Eli looks at the stump in the bucket. 108B INT DOCTOR CRANE’S PRACTICE/OPERATING ROOM DAY:

A fly lands on Charlie’s mouth. Eli chases it away, wipes brother’s brow. Eli sits back down. Behind him, the doctor is washing his hands. Noise in the vestibule. The doctor’s little girl has come home. Father and daughter speak in hushed tones. Then father and little girl enter the room. Doctor Crane looks worried.
Sir, there are men asking about you.
What men?

In the street. Three of them. Eli lifts the curtain and looks across the street. There silhouette in front of the saloon/ general store. The guy is not trying to hide. He nods, swaggering. He lo like a killer. Eli cautiously opens the door a chink.
Rex, shit !
Eli?
Yes!
Is it true that Charlie is out of the game?
What do you want?  83.

Me? Nothing. The Commodore sent me. It’s been a while since you left and he’s growing impatient. Eli peers into the street and sees two other silhouettes behind him. When he looks back, he sees Charlie on the ta
(to the doctor) Is there a back door?
Yes.

Go, go, go, go, go! Charlie, Charlie get up ! We have to go. Eli is about to lift Charlie to carry him. Charlie opens eyes and uses his good arm to grasp Eli’s collar. Eli doe not understand. Charlie hangs on. Stares into his eyes, without letting u His stare is tantamount to an order. He shakes his head in an irrevocable “no”. Eli puts him back down. Charlie’s eyes remain glued to hi
Do I have to come in and get you?
No, I’m coming out!
First you toss your guns, then come out with your hands up! Eli goes to look for Charlie’s Colts. He slips them into back of his pants and undoes his belt.
He opens the door, tosses his belt and raises his hands.
Good. Come on out and talk! Seen from behind, the butts of Charlie’s Colts stick up i his pants.  84. 110 INT DOCTOR CRANE’S PRACTICE/OPERATING ROOM DAY:

Charlie lies on the operating table. His eyes are open. H hears voices. When the first gun goes off, his stump goes to draw. Bullets shatter a window pane. The doctor and his daughte crouch. 111 EXT CRANE’S TOWN STREET DAY: Two men lie sprawled across the street. One of them screa in pain. Eli steps over and shoots him in the head. The third man crawls to take shelter. Rex. Eli walks towa him, crushes his back with his boot.
Are there others behind you? Before Rex answers, Eli fires.
The brothers gallop on Rex’s horses, new boots and spurs their feet.

They try to find their buried treasure. But the mountain shifted and the spot is unrecognizable. Charlie finally finds the fork in the tree and tries to l up with it. All he can see are the disheveled fir trees, a box of matches spilled on a table.
Come on, let’s go. Charlie looks around. Distraught.

The sound of a cavalcade approaching. A group of horsemen gallops by. Hidden by the rocks, Eli watches them ride by. When he ca longer hear them, he comes out of his hiding place, pulli his horse by his tether.  85. Charlie leans over the horse’s neck to grab the reins wit his good hand. He puts the reins in his left hand, spurs the horse and passes in front. Eli follows him.

Darkness. Flashes of light and muted gunfire in the distance. We mo in slowly. CUT TO. Sheltered behind the trunks of felled trees, Eli shoots i the shadows. The shadows shoot back. Crouched next to him, Charlie reloads guns as best he can with a bad hand.

The horses! Get the horses to safety! Charlie makes the horses lie down and lies down alongside them. Charlie’s face against the horse’s side. He closes his eyes. For the first time, he is afraid. FADE TO...
A wide, flat landscape. On one end, the two brothers gall followed on the other end by four men who start shooting them. In the distance, gunshots and smoke. FADE TO...

Two men lie on the ground, dead. One of them has his foot still caught in his horse’s stirrup. Charlie searches the bodies, grabs their weapons and ammo, and hands them to E who's still on his horse. FADE TO...  86.
Galloping again. The horses’ immaculate white coat. FADE TO...
They have built a fire. Charlie cries. Eli changes his brothers bandage wrapped u around bloody stump. woe oe As he stands guard and finishes eating, Eli discreetly watches him.
Rex and Sanchez, and those other guys we didn’t even know... You really think it’s a good idea to go back up north?
Well you know very well why were going north. And you know what we still have left to do.
