I lost the hand that I work with. You'll be on your own on this. Charlie lets go of the powder flask. Eli wants to help immediately, but stays where he is. Charlie has seen that keeps trying. Eli can’t look at his brother struggling with the gun.
Are you ashamed of me? Charlie’s eyes well with tears.
Do you mean what your saying?
Everything has fucking changed so much.  87.
No, nothing has changed. You’re my little brother and I love you. Eli empties his pan in the fire. It sizzles and smokes.
In a week, we'll be in Oregon City, and I‘1l kill the Commodore.
Charlie is lying asleep near the embers. Eli stands guard He hears his brother's sobs getting lost in the stillness the night.
The sun is beating down. The two brothers are riding slowly. At one point, Eli sto around: empty landscape as the eye can see.
Hey, have you noticed how long it’s been since anyone’s tried to kill us?
I don’t know... three, four days ?
Don’t you find that strange? Charlie turns around now. He also finds it strange. 119: INT/ EXT BARN OREGON CITY DAY. Final rehearsal. Charlie repeats one last time.
You walk in the front door. Take the staircase on the right, go up make a left, the office is on the second door on the left.
How many guys are up there with him usually?  88.

Usually there’s a guy sitting right outside the office. And one in the room further down. They load their guns. 120 EXT COMMODORE’S MANSION OREGON CITY- DAY: With his remaining hand, still damaged, Charlie slips a g in his belt. The brothers enter the town, which is strangely deserted. They walk up the street. In the distance, a black cloth h been striated around the large door of the Commodore's mansion. People scurry about underneath, as if waiting for somethi 121 INT. COMMODORE’S MANSION OREGON CITY- DAY: The Sisters brothers are standing side by side in a wood- paneled parlor. Eli takes off his hat. Charlie follows suit. Behind them, townsfolk dressed in black, sitting on two r of benches. In front of them: an open coffin. Inside, the Commodore's corpse, lying on ice. An undertaker is standing nearby, waiting to hammer the l on.
(softly) Fuck! You must be disappointed. A beat.
Yeah, kinda.
Sir? I think no one else may be coming. May we close the casket?
Sure.  89. They put on their hats and start to leave.

Hold on. Eli turns around, steps back to the coffin, gun in hand, brings it slamming down on the dead man’s face. An unpleasant cracking sound. Ice cubes bounce on the woo floor. General astonishment. Eli raises his hand to calm everyon down.
Just making sure. Then they leave.
They gallop out of town and up to the plain. The evening falls. Their conversation continues, indistinct in the distance.
The sun is about to rise. At a bend in the road, a modest farm appears: barn, stables, farmyard, fenced in vegetabl patch. As Eli and Charlie head up the slope, a woman appears in doorway.
Hey, if you come any closer I'll shoot you!
It’s us Ma’.
It’s your sons, it’s Charlie and Eli!
My sons? Oh my god, well why, why did you come, why did you come back?  90.
To see you Ma’.
If you came here to hide or to run away from something you just turn around, I don’t wanna see ya!
No we're tired Ma’. We just want to come home.
We just came here to see you. I swear.
Please?

Eli watches his mother’s old hand stroking Charlie’s face They speak, but he does not hear what they are saying. He walks around the house, his eyes lingering on the wall he finds the a measuring rod, marked with names and numbe Charlie, a date, a height, Eli, a date, a height. He pushes open the door to their bedroom. Their beds are there, one on each side of the room. Behind him, he hears the voices of Charlie and their moth Eli sits down, pulls off his boots, lies down on the bed, soothed by their voices. He stares at the piece of cloth over the window, gently billowing in the breeze. Lulled by its back and forth, hi eyelids grow heavy. His feet are twenty inches too long f the bed. On the floor, through the curtains’ sway, the breaking li of day. THE END.
